cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that instances of the subject concept characteristically or commonly include the object as a recurring element or motif.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Fairytales are characterized by timeless themes.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a narrative genre or story type typically includes a given theme, motif, or other narrative element as part of its content.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Fairytales often include fantastical creatures as part of their stories.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The myth of Pygmalion and Galatea prefigures or functions as the earliest known version of the Beauty and the Beast narrative.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject narrative or myth functions as a source, precursor, or formative influence for the specified later narrative.

qualifiers.CausalHint: can be found in the works of Ovid

remarks: Relation name chosen to capture that it is not a one-to-one retelling but an early form/influence.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a narrative genre, category, or story type characteristically or commonly includes the given motif, theme, character type, or other narrative element as part of its content.
args.justification: All five relations connect a narrative category (fairytales or timeless stories) to recurring motifs, themes, or character types that are commonly present in those narratives. They currently use slightly divergent canonical names ('typically_features', 'features_narrative_element', 'features_motif') and two closely related classes ('narrative_motif_relation', 'narrative_element_relation'). Normalizing to a single predicate 'typically_features' with a unified description and a broader class 'narrative_content_relation' removes unnecessary variation while accurately capturing that these links are about typical narrative content elements under COMPOSITION.
args.remark: Rel_cls_group remains COMPOSITION as already set on each relation instance.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a narrative genre, category, or story type characteristically or commonly includes the given motif, theme, character type, or other narrative element as part of its content.
executed_decisions.justification: All five relations connect a narrative category (fairytales or timeless stories) to recurring motifs, themes, or character types that are commonly present in those narratives. They currently use slightly divergent canonical names ('typically_features', 'features_narrative_element', 'features_motif') and two closely related classes ('narrative_motif_relation', 'narrative_element_relation'). Normalizing to a single predicate 'typically_features' with a unified description and a broader class 'narrative_content_relation' removes unnecessary variation while accurately capturing that these links are about typical narrative content elements under COMPOSITION.
executed_decisions.remark: Rel_cls_group remains COMPOSITION as already set on each relation instance.
